ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I would have liked to have other outside folks come and speaker to the class more. We had two outside speakers (Rob F andPavan Sukhdev) and a de facto speaker (one of Ben's grad student's whose name I am forgetting). I really enjoyed hearing their perspectives.Less student-led, more speakers, please!

it was awesome to learn more about forest certification. i think the course was a bit incorrectly named- it was essentially about cerification and the professor's approach to analyzing the effectiveness of that tool. shorter reading would have been great! i really liked the process of writing and working on the paper. i am not sure the utility of learning such a specific thought process (likely little), but it was interesting!
Students of this class might benefit from more direct lectures from the instructor. As a foundation forgrasping the poli science concepts and theories, which were new to many of the students.
Course provides a strong theoretical background and is challenging for policy and non-policy students. Would be great to have more PhD students present as students or teaching fellows.

12) The course was far to theoretical and not applicable at all to how I will be dealing with CSR in myprofessional career10) There definitely should have been a lecture component to the course, and the instructor should have done a much better job and facilitating and guiding the class. He does give helpful feedback on the papers.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The discussions were great, Ben provided some great insights
review of material about the topic. lots of material!
I really enjoyed learning from Professor Cashore and wish there had been a little bit more time for lecture. The readings were great as well.
getting to decide your own paper topic. running two classes was also fun

We covered the issue of CSR from a number of viewpoints - historical, commodity-specific, political science, economics, and so forth. The class discussion were for the most part very stimulating and interesting .

Discussion sections were enlightening and intellectual stimulating.Te instructor's emphasis on problem solving and not just problem analysis and statements - formulating theories was new and beneficial for meHis open door policy, even though he is very busy was a good resource when writing the final paperFinal paper was a great way for each student to dig more into topic of interest
Readings and focus on theory and policy was great.
The best aspects of the course were the myriad opportunities that students had to apply CSR scholarship and ideas to issues of great personal interest to them.
The application of engineering concepts into environmental science
Readings and consults with the Prof. were valuable.
The feedback we got on our assignments
It was thorough and refreshing take on the topic from many different perspectives. It felt "useful."
The course was a good introduction to corporate social responsibility, the broad field that it encompasses and the potential for environmental impact of the concept.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: If Ben could be a bit more responsive to the students, the class would be much better. It was difficult to get in touch with Ben outside of class and we had to reschedule at least a third of our classes due to his travel schedule, which is fine, I understand he had to go to conferences, but it was difficult to have an ongoing class with him absent so often.
Less allowing the same 3 people to dominate the conversations. I would have preferred Ben lead more classes or have outside speakers.
It would have been helpful to have 45 minutes - 1 hour set aside at the beginning of each class for lecture.

no feedback whatsoever on the memos or class organizing. it would be great to bring the CSR discussion out a bit - more broad. itfelt like there were two groups in class - people who got the lingo and people who were new.

I would really like to see more lectures from Prof Cashore - the ones we had were fantastic. While my fellow students did a great job presenting every week, taking a few sessions for the Professor to really go into the basic CSR frameworks would have been useful.
Need for additional lectures and maybe guests speakers who are responsible for CSR practices in firms and multilateral organizations

Course would benefit from smaller class size. Also, more emphasis and time spent on how to present, write empirical policy papers and response papers would be appreciated. These are important skills that are worth taking time to develop from a policy perspective.
The seminar discussions sometimes gasped for air, and it would be helpful to have some more gentle steering on topics and ideas during class.
ensuring that all projects are feasible
The class discussions needed more structure. I think we needed more explanation of concepts and theories before jumping into student-led discussions each week.

The style of the course wasn't helpful--the students were supposed to lead the course--but no one had any idea what they were talking about so I didn't get very much out of the discussions. Many of the students have very applicable work experience but the way the class was run and the focus on theory rather than the application of CSR meant that this wealth of knowledge was barely tapped. I thought that we should have had a lecture component for the first hour or so of class, I wanted to learn from the world expert who was our teacher, instead of just talking with my peers. It was a very frustrating experience overall.
Organization of topics of each class. The way it was now seemed sometimes repetitive and sometimes illogical.

Undoubtedly, the changes in the schedule owing to the other activities of Professor Cashore affected how the course was handled as well as a more in-depth context of the topics under CSR that may have further helped the students appreciate the course.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
No lecture, just discussion.
There were no course lectures unfortunately. There was one the first day and that was the best day of class.
The instructor could also have gave slightly more lecture. Student-led instruction didnt get to the point sometimes and the discussions sometimes were scattered.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It is quite relevant; it'd be nice if we read more relevant papers
I thought it would but now I don't think so.

The course gave me a pretty good introduction to and understanding of environmentally relevant CSR practices in firms and got me thinking about their motivation for participating. This way of thinking will be advantageous when creating avenues for firms in my home country to become involved with sustainability issues.
Fits with policy work.
This is my first real class on CSR (other than Corporate Environmental Management and Strategy).
It gives me tools for policy evaluation
I have a policy/advocacy background. The class was helpful in helping me to understand the existing theories about current governance changes.

It doesn't. I took the course because I wanted to know how CSR works and I feel like I really don't have much better understanding than when I started. If I work for an NGO involved in these efforts I am not sure how much I will have to contribute. The one thing that I did find helpful was thinking and learning about problem definition.

My thesis deals with reforestation conducted by multi-stakeholders. These stakeholders involve different sectors attempting to work together and thus how the private sector appreciates working with both government and non-profit affects how effective the reforestation will be pursued. Thus CSR is relevant in appreciating the orientation of corporations.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because I'll most likely work in a CSR/sustainability department in private industry
It sounded interesting
wanted to learn from ben cashore and consider private sector motivations for sustainable practice.
I became interested in CSR, but wanted to take more than just a survey course of CSR, like Mariann's class. Ben's rigorous, thoughtful approach was exactly what I was looking for.
Please see 17 above
Improve background in theory and policy in environmental governance.
I took this course to develop a real-world understanding of how CSR efforts can be effective in producing some of their desired environmental and social outcomes.
It allows me to build an evaluation framework for urban sustainability
I wanted to take a class with this Prof. I also thought it would help me understand governance issues.
See above

I was exposed to CSR in labor relations that emphasized labor conditions as basis for CSR initiatives. However I have not taken a course on CSR before and with the relevance of the private sector in the development of any country, their responsibility towards the environment is worth appreciating.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes and no; we covered new material I was interested in, but felt like we only got to the very basics of CSR
No.
yes and no
Yes - I have much more of a nuanced and informed approach to thinking about and promoting CSR strategies, which is what I was hoping for.
Yes.
Yes, the knowledge gained in this course far exceeded even my high expectations and I will continue to draw from these perspectives in my professional career.
unfortunately I didn't have a chance to apply the most important tools in my project

Yes. I found some of the readings and analytical frameworks extremely useful. I would have liked it if the Prof. had split the class half lecture / half discussion. This is what I was accustomed to in other seminar-style classes. I think this could have given the class a solid grounding in particular concepts that were taught.
No
Yes, however I feel that a more in depth discussion of the developing theories on CSR may have been better and more deeply discussed and understood.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Groupwork is groupwork. Very dependent on who you work with. One group was great, the other was less great.
Group work was helpful - we were able to feed off of each other's ideas and talk about more difficult concepts together.
Gaining form my colleagues an international perspective on a CSR issue that is local to my home country.Digging into and understanding the material together
Great perspective was gained by sorting through ideas in small discussion groups before class sessions.
advantages: different perspectives and check and balances on approachesdisadvantages: coordinating among people's schedules
Group work was leading discussion together. So figuring out how to present the class together was a helpful experience in terms of managing expectations.

The perspectives of other classmates in class proved valuable in the discussion of the topics for which the classes were divided. Leading the discussions meant requiring the students to fully be responsible in their learning. However, again I feel that while a seminar environment makes the students to contribute more in the class discussion, discussion of theory will have made it more fruitful.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: What their background is and why they want to take it.

if you are interested in certification - do it. take the process tracing and over-theorizing with a grain of salt and make sure you continue to bring the discussion/ your thinking back to "what does this mean for creating positive private sector action?"

I definitely recommend the class - itis academic yet practical, engaging, and nuanced. The political science perspective was completely new to me, and while this made the coursework difficult, I think I am a better thinker because of it.
Be willing to stretch your current way of thinking
If you are willing to read carefully and puzzle through theory, this is a good class for anyone working in policy or advocacy.
ensure that you talk to professors early about your project

The prof. is a wealth of information. He is excellent at listening to questions and giving students the framework through which to analyze any related topic. You will get the most out of the class if you meet with the prof one-on-one to discuss the final paper and other issues.
I wouldn't take it unless you are really interested in the theory behind CSR and a very academic approach to the topic
Good content and points made by the instructor but at the price of scattered class and discussion.
